clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Evaluation of Sutures in Periodontal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Evaluation of Four Types of Suture in Periodontal Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The aims of this study were to evaluate and compare tissue erythema, edema and knot loosening among four types of suture one week after periodontal surgery.

detailed_description.textblock: Forty patients participated in this prospective, randomized, double-blind clinical trial. Vertical mattress sutures were used following resective periodontal surgery performed by one operator. Four suture materials were selected for evaluation: 5-0 silk; 5-0 polypropylene; 5-0 polyglycolic acid (PGA), and 4-0 polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). Seven days after the surgical procedure, the surgeon assessed suture loosening and removed the sutures. A blind researcher clinically evaluated erythema and edema.

primary_outcome.measure: presence or absence of Suture loosening
primary_outcome.description: Seven days after the surgical procedure, the surgeon assessed suture loosening; recording loose or not Loose

secondary_outcome.measure: presence and level of erythema and edema.
secondary_outcome.description: Seven days after the surgical procedure a blind researcher clinically evaluated erythema and edema. Adding a score related to a gingival index

arm_group.description: Four types of suture including silk, polypropylene, PGA, and PTFE

intervention.description: surgical periodontal debridement is performed after periodontal phase I

study_pop.textblock: patients treated at the CUO (dental clinic at the Universitat Internacional de Catalunya) that are prescribed for periodontal resective surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Qualification for the study was based on the need for resective periodontal surgery (apically positioned flap and osseous recontouring) at four or more consecutive interproximal sites per quadrant
Exclusion Criteria:
- systemic diseases, such as diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or an immunologic disease that would affect wound healing; allergies to prescribed medication; and/or current pregnancy or breast feeding were excluded from the study
